In 1904, when the first Comfor monwealth Conciliation and Arbitration and Act was before Parliament, Mr Andrew Fisher moved to include railway employees. What is the object of arbitration? As I conceive it, the principle underlying it, certainly the principle that moved the late Andrew Fisher to bring forward his amendment, and the principle which moved this Government to bring in the present legislation, and past governments, to introduce the amending arbitration acts of 1911 and 1920, and the modifications made from time to time, was an effort to find some better way for the settlement of disputes between employer and employee than resort to force. In order that that might be done, two things were necessary, the first of which was that the men should receive such reasonable wages and be employed under such reasonable conditions as would permit them to enjoy a fair share of the amenities of the state of civilization in which they found themselves, and the second that although a government-controlled railway service is entirely divorced from the capitalistic system inside which it operates, it is an integral part of the industrial system of Australia, and its efficient, economic and harmonious operation depends upon the rates and conditions fixed by the court or tribunal. The railways of Australia are run for the benefit and convenience of the public; .rates and conditions must therefore not only be such as to be fair and reasonable to the employees but also permit of the economic and efficient operation of the service. And it must not be forgotten that the Commonwealth Railways Commissioner has to compete with sea-borne traffic. Further, since the Commonwealth Railways are part of the railway system of Australia, rates and conditions should be, as far as possible, uniform. The employees on our railways must have reasonable rates and conditions, but every one who has had dealings with unions knows that the most potent cause of unrest is differential treatment. While, therefore, the workers must get a fair return for their labour, it is essential that the conditions, as far as possible, should be uniform. How can that uniformity be best assured? By the Arbitration Court, which the party opposite ever since this Parliament was established, believed to be the most effective means for the settlement of disputes and the most efficiently equipped to bring about harmonious and smooth-working in industry, or by the Public Service Arbitrator who has had no experience of railway working and who is not familiar with the conditions obtaining on State railways.

text: -That may he so, but probably a dozen different, unions went to the court at different times. It was the Railways Commissioner who served a log on the union, in which he sought reduced wages and worse conditions. He asked the court to reduce the basic wage fixed by Mr Justice Powers, which had been in operationfor nine years, and he asked that other things, which had been provided for in the award of the court, should heleft to him to decide. In self-protection the unions lodged counter claims, but at the conclusion of the case the men found that, in many instances, 'they had suffered reductions. Every adult on the job working on a daily-paid basis lost the Is. 3d. a day which the award of the court had previously provided, and for some grades for which margins higher than the basic wage were previously fixed, the margins were either reduced or wiped out. The special recognition which prevailed in the Commonwealth Railways, operating on a route where there was no seaport town other than Port Augusta, and where the climate was severe, was wiped out. This recognition, which afforded some compensation to the men and their families, was withdrawn by the award of the court, and even the district allowances originally granted by the department, and afterwards incorporated in the awards, were, at the request of the Commissioner, left to his discretion. I recollect the Commissioner's advocate saying, during the hearing of the case, that the allowances were too high. I do not suggest that every alteration of the award was to the disadvantage of the men, but the benefits they derived from it were for comparatively few. The award, as a whole, was received' by the great majority of the men with tremendous disappointment, and was regarded as a severe set-back from which they would seek the earliest means of escape. Some of the more .active spirits desired to resort to direct action, and threatened to do so, arguing that adherence to arbitration had created .a false impression in the minds of those in authority; but the officials of the various organizations counselled them to stay their hands. I am not speaking now - of the locomotive men only, though I was more closely associated - with them than with the others. I know that, had we said the word, a strike would have - occurred, resulting in great loss to the - department, and great inconvenience to the public. This bill is the reward which the men have received for the patience they displayed. The Minister in charge of the bill, his book The Case for Labour, pub21,000, lished in 1910, states on page 138The wage-earners have fought bitterly and .long for better conditions; without they could have done nothing. Unions have done much. But they will not do everything. As the cause of bad industrial conditions is to be found in bad laws, it is by legislative reform that permanent and effective improvement of the wage-earner's condition is to be found. Unfortunately, the right honourable gentleman who wrote those lines is now the agency through which those rights are to be taken away. I venture to suggest that, if that section of the employees which it is now proposed should be deprived of their rights was large in numbers, and was spread throughout Australia instead of being confined to only two of the States, both the Government and the Minister would have paused before proceeding with this measure, if , indeed, in those circumstances, such a measure would ever have been drafted. The - political steam-hammer is being used to crack a nut of small size, but of great significance. This is being done as a matter of expediency in the interests, not of the Government itself, but of some influential authority, which sees in the present system a prospect of the railway employees being placed on a similar footing to their fellow employees in other branches of the Public Service. The principle of separating the public servants of the Commonwealth from the rest of the workers, insofar as the regulation of their wages and working conditions are concerned, was fought for by this Government. That principle was evolved by the same kind of political thought as that which now controls this Parliament, yet now, for reasons ol expediency only, the Government asks the House to abrogate that principle. What justification can be offered for the separation of 1,000 men in one particular branch from the rest of the Commonwealth Public Service? The Minister in charge of the bill put forward the argument that, as railway men generally go to the federal court, Commonwealth railway employees also should go there. It will be found, on inquiry, that the railway men in Queensland and Western in Australia, who number approximately do not apply to that court for redrnss of their grievances. The New South Wales locomotive men, numbering, unions at the minimum, 3,500, are working under a State award, and there is a considerable disparity between the margins fixed by the State court and the Federal court for two important sections of the men, the electric train drivers and the cleaners. The margin fixed for the electric train drivers was increased from 7s. to Ss. a day by the State court, while almost at the same time the federal court reduced the margin from 7s. to 6s. The State court increased the margin for engine cleaners, but the federal court wiped it out. The federal court, itself, has referred the railway men, who are members of the Australian Railwaymen's Union, to a State tribunal, the Victorian Railways Classification Board. It is claimed by the Australian ways Union that its membership is approximately 17,000, but, as some of the members may be covered by awards given for artisans, it may be reasonably stated that the Victorian Railways Classification Board will deal with the conditions of approximately 15,000 railway employees. The action of referring the. claims of the Railway Commissioners and the railway employees to the Victorian Railways Classification Board was taken by His Honour Judge Drake-Brockman, under section 36 of the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Act. He will have the final voice, but the work of investigation will be done by the State employers' tribunal. When the railway employees desire the Public Service Arbitrator, instead of the court, to investigate and decide their case, they are confronted by this bill, which proposes to prevent it. The Public Service (Arbitration) Act 1920 was designed to provide the advantage of preventing varying decisions leading to trouble and difficulty in administration within the Public Service. How can it reasonably be expected that some of the Commonwealth Government's employees will be satisfied with conditions of employment which are greatly inferior to those applying to the great majority of the employees? Can they be expected to view without resentment the fact that the Commonwealth Railways officers are provided for by the awards of the Public Service Arbitrator, whilst they are to be prohibited from having their case dealt, with by that authority? As far back as 1920 the Public Service Mr Drakeford. Arbitrator, then a different person from the gentleman now occupying the position, ordered AA hours a week in his awards for daily-paid workers. A 44hour week did not become general until a somewhat later stage, but it is practically the standard for daily-paid workers covered by awards of the Arbitrator, and it has been so for a decade. The awards provide shorter hours for men who are on night duty, and .who work broken shifts, and they allow for overtime rates after a standard day has been worked. The Federal Court allows the employer to work men up to ten hours in any day without any overtime payments, and then a rate of only time and a quarter prevails up to eleven hours. It is quite possible Rail- for men to work ten hours and travel for work purposes up to twelve, fourteen or more hours, during which period they can be called upon for work at any minute, without receiving any overtime payment, because the travelling is at a passive rate which does not carry penalties. For men operating trains, the federal court, at the request of the employer, decreased the overtime rates, after ten hours work, from time and a half to time and a quarter, and the same court has indicated that, if the desire to have a weekly day of rest, asked for by the men, is granted, it might "have to consider a further extension to the claim for consideration. Whilst, in most parts of the world, efforts are being made to prevent overtime, and thus .spread employment over as wide a field as possible, the liberty of the employer to work men overtime has been extended. A factor that is always stressed in the court is the economic position of the railways throughout Australia. The deficits, wilfully created in most cases by inadequate freight charges and by the building of lines for developmental purposes to places which it was known beforehand would not provide .an adequate revenue, are trotted out by the skilful advocates of the departments as showing that no improvement should be given to the employees, if the economic conditions of the railways are to be given due consideration. Enhanced land values created by the building of the lines do not pass to the credit of the Governments representby ing the people of the States on whose behalf the lines have been constructed. A rake-off is provided for the land-holder or speculator when the laud is sold at enhanced values, but if the land becomes unprofitable to work, it leads to a for a reduction of transportation rates or outcasts! and for subsidies to the men on the land. Revenue derived from the opening of land for exploitation, such as timber royalties, and land tax, where it operates, goes not to the Railways Department, but to other departments. If the land served by the railways, including that in city areas, were subject to reasonCommonwealth able taxation, and the proceeds were applied as a set-off to reductions of climatic freight and fares, the railways as a translocation, distance port agency would continue to have pride population, of place, and would be held up to the of public as a. substantial benefit, instead of the hopeless burden they depicted as being today. The farmers would benefit, and so would the public and the railway workers. We should not have the spectacle of railway manageworkers ments being forced to plead financial losses to prevent the employees f getting fair treatment. The Commonwealth railways, above others, were never expected to pay. Transcontinental line was built to provide a service between the western and eastern half of the continent as an obligation to the people of Western Australia their entering the federation, and as provision for defence purposes. Alice Springs railway is an extension of a line which was known to be a hopeless burden when it only to Oodnadatta, but completed in fulfilment of a promise made to South Australia. Only by the development of large gold or oil-bearing territory could it prove commercially profitable. Yet those working on this North-south line, which over almost every mile, of it traverses desert country, confronted with its failure to produce profit when their wages and working conditions are being considered, and deficits are added to the others to make up a weight of evidence against them getting shorter hours or improved conditions. This line is as much ji national service as that rendered the Meteorological Department, the Defence Department and others which spend much but produce little direct revenue. Yet the railwaymen are to be put into an inferior class to their colleagues in those departments, and are to demand become Commonwealth Service pariahs No one claims that the majority of up Commonwealth employees .are too well treated through being given a 44-hour week, but this Government is denying the railway men their chance of obtaining it. District allowances are fixed for all branches of the Public Service, except daily-paid railway men. on a common basis, in accordance with disadvantages, geographical from centres of and concomitant lack social amenities. No distinction is made between post office officials are and officers of the Department of the Interior, yet there is a definite and wide distinction between the district allowance for postal workers aud that of railway at, say, Alice Springs. In that town we have two sets of employees, both r o m working for Commonwealth instrumentalities, the railway employee reall ceiving an allowance of Is. a day, or The £18 5s. per annum, and the postal employee receiving £50 a year, if married, and £30 a year, if single. text: The railway employees did not go to the Public Service Arbitrator for sixteen years.

Speaker: Mr DRAKEFORD
Title: WOOL TAX ASSESSMENT BILL
text: The locomotivemen went twice - to the court, ancl were taken back to it by the Commissioner, after awards which they had previously obtained had been set aside by that court. Then they, went to the Public Service Arbitrator. Surely the Government still wants to avoid the disadvantage of " varying decisions leading to trouble and difficulty in administration ". Surely the Ministry, and those honourable members who support it, desire to bring about conditions which, instead of creating friction, will cause " a greater amount of confidence in the administration of the Public Service, through the officers having a just tribunal to deal with their rights". If they do, they must vote against the second reading of this bill, which takes away the right of access to a tribunal set up by a government of the same type as that which they support. If honourable members opposite can but put themselves for a little while in the place of the men-affected, they will have no difficulty in arriving at the view that the bill is unwarranted, and that much more substantial reasons will have to be given, if indeed, any sound reason can be found, for the carrying of a measure which w restrictive in its action, repudiates the principles contained in the bill sought to be amended, is harsh, and is manifestly unjust to a law-abiding section of the Public Service whose interests it affects. The railway men are aware that the Public Service Arbitrator awards a 44-hour week, and they know now, since the Commonwealth Arbitration Court has had the opportunity to deal with the pubmatter, that it does not do so. In such circumstances, how can it be expected that they will be other than dissatisfied ? Where is the " consistent whole which the Minister in 1920 said would be one of the advantages arising from the appointment of a Public Service Arbitrator ? It will be seen that the inference that railway men, as a rule, seek the aid of the Arbitration Court, rather than that of other tribunals, is not correct. The Commonwealth railway men knew that there was another channel open to them, and they made themselves familiar in a general way with what results had followed from the use of that channel. They saw that their fellow public servants in practically all other branches of the Commonwealth activities-daily-pai d workers like themselves-obtaine d a 44-hour week without reduction of pay, and payment when off on sick leave; that the provision of district allowances was not left to the discretion of the employer; and that they were provided for in the matter of long-service leave or furlough. The employees did not always get what they claimed, but they accepted what they did not like as cheerfully a 3 they could, and looked with some hope, down an avenue provided by the law, upon a distant and more alluring future. This year the Government has brought forward a proposal to prevent " the rights and privileges of the Public Service"' being " worked out as a consistent whole". .Surely those honourable members who supported that principle in 1920 will not stand for its abrogation now. According to Hansard of the 3rd September, 1920, page 4200, the right honourable member who has introduced the present bill stated in this House I repeat that all the bill proposes to do is to create a Public Service Arbitration Court. . . . Honourable members must admit that this will be a far better method of dealing with Public Service affairs than that which exists today, where a judge of the Commonweal th Court of Conciliation and Arbitration is required to give so much of his attention to a Public Service matter arising as he may be able to spare in the course of dealing with industrial problems emanating from any and every industry throughout the land. . . . This is a b i ll which violates no precedent and introduces no innovation. It rests upon abundant precedent. And yet this same gentleman, representing the Acting Attorney-General in a similar kind of government is now introducing legislation which is taking away the advantages derived from the bill which he introduced in 1920. When one reads the debates relating to the creation and development of the system of Public Service arbitration, in which the right honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Hughes) has played so important and so great a part in the past, and when one goes back into the records and realizes how stern a fight he made for the principle that all public servants should have access to the tribunal, one cannot help but marvel at the extraordinary changes which time political circumstances have brought about. I feel sure that the right honorin able gentleman cannot be happy in the task which is placed in his hands today. I feel certain that his heart cannot liis job, and that he does not willingly sacrifice all the things for which he stood throughout the years, in an endeavour, as a mere matter of political expediency, to wreck the principles on which the system of conciliation and arbitration the Public Service was founded. I ask that consideration be given to the tion of deferring this bill until the vernment has given further thought its effect on a comparatively small ber of worthy citizens rendering faithbers ful and efficient service under unfavorwas able and unusual conditions, whose claims to be treated in the same manner as their fellow workers in the Public Service, living mostly under more favourable conditions, are unanswerable, and should not be denied by any deliberative body which contends that its legislative enactments are based upon a reasonable conception of right, truth and justice. I conclude by saying that tliere are many other reasons which could be advanced against the introduction of this bill, the object of which must be clear to everybody. I think that honourable members will agree that the Minister in charge of the bill has not put up a convincing case in its favour. As I have said., this bill has been introduced as a matter of political expediency, and has resulted from the efforts of influential persons to take away the right of certain persons to approach a particular tribunal for the settlement of disputes. I remind honourable members that, if this bill is passed, and it is subsequently found that it inflicts an injustice on a section of the workers, it will be very difficult to have it repealed. The Minister has stated that the bill and its complementary measure are not to be regarded as party proposals. I appeal to him, and to honourable members generally, that, in fairness to the railway men concerned, they should both be withdrawn, and that the railway men should be extended the measure of justice for which they have been struggling for many years.

text: Darling and Downs) [5.35] - I ask honourable members to cast their minds back to earlier years, order to see the.position in which, we were placed when this principle was first introduced. In 1911, an Arbitration be in (Public Service) Act was passed, and later there was enacted the Arbitration (Public .Service) Act 1920. In 1917, the Commonwealth Railways Act was passed, which provided that the Arbitration (Public Service) Act of -1911 was to in apply to the railway service in like manner as it applied to the public serquesvants of the 'Commonwealth. The matGoter was raised . by the Arbitration to (Public .Service) Act of 1920, and numthe question which honourable memwere then called upon to decide whether the definition clause in that act was sufficiently wide to include, and if, in fact, it did include, Commonwealth railway servants. During the progress of the debate on the bill the opinion of the legal advisers of the Government was expressed that railway servants were included in the definition, and that it was intended to include them. At that time, railway employees in the service of the States throughout Australia excluded from the Commonwealth Arbitration Act, because of an interpretation placed upon the meaning of the Constitution by the High Court. There was, therefore, no power in the Arbitration Act to deal with Federal and State railway employees over the whole of the Commonwealth. A bill was introduced to deal with the Public Service of the Commonwealth, and the remarks which I then made, and which have been quoted by the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Drakeford), directed towards securing what was then really aimed at, the provision of uniform legislation to cover the whole of the Commonwealth public servants throughout the Commonwealth. That principle still applies today. In 1911 the definition of " industrial dispute" in the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Act included Commonwealth public authorities, and Commonwealth Public servants engaged in an interstate dispute. Speaker: Mr BARNARD
Title: WOOL TAX ASSESSMENT BILL
text: Bass) [ 5 . 4 5 ] - I have listened with interest to the introductory speech of the Minister, and the speeches of the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Drakeford) and the honourable member for Darling Downs (Sir Littleton Groom). From the history of this legislation, which he traced back as far as 1920, the honourable member for Darling Downs made the deduction that the proposal. which the Government is now putting before .us should be supported in the interests of uniformity . To my mind, that is a deplorably weak argument. Uniformit y of hours of work and wages is never likely to be achieved through the Commonwealth Arbitration Court. The workers, having realized this unfortunate fact, are d r if t in g away a l " , from the court. This is due largely to the outlook of the judges of the court, whose talk from the Bench about such matters as promotion by senility has undermined the confidence of the workers in the court itself. The gentlemen who have been appointed to the Bench of the Arbitration Court of late years have held views which give the workers little reason for confidence. That they adhere after their elevation to the Bench to the views they previously held has been indicated very clearly in recent awards, and notably in that made to cover Commonwealth railway employees. The whole procedure of the court is causing dissatisfaction, delay and irritation, and is not making for industrial peace. The railway workers have on several occasions obtained awards from the court, but they have only been waiting for the expiry of the award that has been in operation for the last two or three years so that they could approach the Public Service Arbitrator. They hoped that their claims would be more justly considered by h im than they have been by the court. The recent award of the court was so unsatisfactory to the men that they threatened to. cease work unless certain of their grievances were rectified. Unhappily, the judges of the Arbitration Court often declare that they will will not deal with certain claims submitted to them on the ground that their jurisdiction is limited, and advise the men to approach some other authority or make an appeal to the legislature. Can it be expected that such a procedure will satisfy men suffering under a sense of injustice? The Minister in charge of this bill must be aware of these facts. If he is ignorant of them, he is amazingly indifferent to current events. The Arbitration Court has caused intense dissatisfaction among the workers generally for its failure to deal with the applications made to it for a shorter working week. This dissatisfaction has become acute in the Commonwealth railway service. The excuse advanced on behalf of the court is that such a matter must be dealt with by three judges, and it is asserted that, while so many matters are awaiting the attention of judges who can sit in single jurisdiction, it would not be appropriate for the three judges to withdraw their attention from other matters to deal with the applications for a shorter working week. But surely matters of major importance should have priority of attention from the judges. If necessary, the hearing of a claim affecting, say, a few hundred men should be postponed to deal with claims affecting thousands of men. The declaration of the Ministei' that the Government intended to take action to apply to the Commonwealth railway service the long-service leave conditions applicable to the railway workers of Western Australia will be entirely satisfactory to the Commonwealth railway employees. Long-service leave is at present granted in the railway services of Queensland, New South Wales, South Australia, Western Australia and Tasmania, and it is only proper that it should be granted to Commonwealth railway employees. I also submit that Commonwealth railway employees should be entitled to the same district allowances as are granted to Commonwealth public servants generally. Why should the Commonwealth railway employees be expected to accept r-onditions inferior to those enjoyed by employees in other branches of the Commonwealth Service ? Equity demands that "qual consideration shall be given to all. The honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Drakeford) dealt briefly with f he important subject of working hours. I desire to deal with the subject at greater length. The Commonwealth railway employees are unfavorably situated in regard to their working as compared with the employees of the State railways. According to the Commonwealth Year-Booh. No. 28, which is the latest available, in 1934, there were Mr Barnard. 93,917 railway employees in Australia, of whom 14,772 were on salary, and 79,145 on wages. The hours worked by the salaried staff may be said to be less than 44 a week; probably the average would be even less than 40 a week, so that approximately 15,000 of the employees are working less than 40 hours a week. This leaves approximately 79,000 daily-paid workers who work for 44 hours a week or more. Of these, 55,000 are employed on the railway systems of New South Wales, Queensland and Western Australia, the respective figures being 33,968, 13,854 and 7,154. The remainder are employed on the railway systems of Victoria, South Australia and Tasmania, the respective figures being 17,450, 5,563, and 1,156. Approximately, 24,000 workers appear, at first sight, to be employed on a 48-hour basis. But from these must be eliminated the artisans and those associated with them. This would probably reduce the number by at least 4,000, leaving not more than 20,000 of the number employed ou the State railway services who are on a 44-hour week. That is a very conservative estimate. At page 168 of the Year-Booh, from which I have already quoted, figures will be found showing that at the time the statistics were prepared, about 1,300 persons were employed on Commonwealth railways, of whom 171 were salaried officers working for 44 hours a week or less. At least another 200 of the employees would be artisans or their assistants who would be working 44 hours a week. This leaves about 900 employees on a 48-hour week basis. As business has improved somewhat, these numbers would now be somewhat greater, but the proportion would not be altered. From this it will be seen that a considerable number-in fact, the great majority-of the railway employees in Australia work not more than 44 hours a week. In the Commonwealth railway service, however, the great majority of the daily-paid employees work 48 hours a week. I am pleased that the Government of Tasmania has decided to apply a 44hours hour working week to its employees. The hours of work in the railway services of the various States vary somewhat. Locomotive engine-drivers in the New South Wales service work 88 hours a fortnight. Queensland railway workers enjoy a 44-hour week, and so do those of Western Australia.. When the Tasmanian railway workers are placed on a 44-hour week, as from the 1st July, a considerable measure of uniformity will be achieved, but I cannot see how anything effective to that end is likely to be done by our acceptance of the proposal which the Commonwealth Government is now submitting to us. The recent awards of the Commonwealth Arbitration Court have shown clearly that its judges are decades behind the times in their outlook, and seem to have no regard for modern developments. The result is that the only employees who approach the court are those who are forced to do so. The railway coinmissfoners are almost compelling employees to approach the court, doubtless because they hold the opinion that it will grant conditions less attractive to the employees, and more attractive to themselves. The judges of the Arbitration Court take into consideration the capacity of an industry to pay. The honourable member for Maribyrnong has pointed out that the Transcontinental railway was built, not with the idea that it would be a payable proposition, but for quite a different reason. In the Arbitration Court the representatives of the commissioners never fail to produce balance sheets of the year's operations and to stress the losses that have been made. The presiding judge uses those losses as a reason for refusing to reduce the number of hours or to improve the working conditions. This principle has been applied in the Commonwealth court against not only Commonwealth railway employees, but abo the employees of other instrumentalities, with the result that in New South Wales the men are working under a State award which raised their wages and improved their working conditions after the Commonwealth court had refused to concede what they claimed. The Queensland railway men approached the federal court on one occasion and were glad to keep, away from it thereafter. Working under an award of the State Arbitration Court they now enjoy higher wages and better working conditions. The men in Western Australia occupy a similar position. Yet the honourable member for Darling Downs (Sir Littleton Groom) says that this bill makes for uniformity! It does nothing of the kind. Although some of the railway systems are allegedly working under an award of the federal court, the governments of those States have determined that a working week shall not exceed 44 hours. The last to come into line is the Government of Tasmania. In that State the men enjoy long service leave, and are now to have a shorter working week. These are concessions of the government, not of the Arbitration Court, which says that it can exercise no control over such privileges as long service leave, district allowances, and other privileges which Commonwealth employees are seeking to obtain. If the Commonwealth Government desires to achieve greater uniformity and to have the matter of wages and working conditions determined by the federal court, it must first bring its employees into line with the majority of railway men throughout Australia, by administratively granting those privileges. I am opposed to the bill in the absence of a declaration by the Government as to its intentions in regard to hours and working conditions.

Speaker: Mr MCBRIDE
Title: WOOL TAX ASSESSMENT BILL
text: Grey) [8.20] - I have a particular interest in the bill now beforethe House, not only because of the principle involved, but also because many of the men who will be affected by this measure are resident in the electoratewhich I represent. It is, therefore, my duty, when considering this proposed legislation, to assess, as well as I can,. its probable effect upon the men concerned. It must be rather disturbing to many of us, who have for' years supported the principle of arbitration, to hear the astounding accusations that have been made against the Federal Arbitration Court in its dealings with Commonwealth railway workers. In the past, while I have always been a staunch supporter of arbitration, I confess that I entertained doubts as to how the workers would react when the economic tide turned, and conditions became such that the arbitration courts, Federal and State, would be compelled to stop granting - further concessions, and to begin reducing wages and varying conditions to the detriment of employees. I desire now to say how much I appreciate the action of the workers throughout Australia in accept ing so loyally the reductions made from time to time by various arbitration tribunals during the time of the depression through which Australia has passed. It seems to me that, as the workers accepted those sacrifices in so fine a spirit, they have now a right, when times have improved, to expect a restoration of the benefits that were taken from them. It is with that idea in mind that I propose to discuss this measure. It is admitted that, until the award 1932, the men, while perhaps not always satisfied, were at least prepared to accept the decisions of the court. It has been stated that they did not, on all - occasions, approach the court, but in 1927 they did so, and accepted the decision of the judge. In 1932, of course, it was the Railways Commissioner who applied to the court, and it is against the award issued in response to that application that the men are now taking - such strong exception. As honourable members will recall, when that award - came out there was a suggestion by some of the men that they should refuse to accept it. As a matter of fact, there was a probability of a strike on the Commonwealth railways. As the representative of the men in this Parliament, I was asked by their officials, while I was in Port Augusta, to discuss the position with them. I agreed to do so, and told them that, as a supporter of arbitration, I could not countenance direct action; - that, as they had appealed to the court on other occasions and accepted its awards, so they must accept the award of the court on this occasion.. I said then, however, as I say now, that while there was an obligation upon the men to observe the award, there was also an obligation upon the Commissioner to make conditions of employment as satisfactory as possible. I pointed out that, although the Government could not countenance any attempt to flout the award of the court, there still remained matters within the control of the Commissioner in regard to which representations might be made to him. I suggested that the men should approach the Commissioner in regard to rent3 for the cottages they occupied. The rents were probably assessed on the cost of construction, the cottages having been built with money borrowed at 5 per cent, or 6 per cent. As the result of conversion operations, the rate of interest had in the meantime been reduced, and it was only reasonable that the benefit of that reduction should be passed on to the men. I do not suggest that anything I had to say to the men on that occasion very greatly influenced them, or that the representations which I made subsequently to the Commissioner swayed him to any great extent. I merely point out of that, when.the men applied to the Commissioner, he did make some very definite concessions. He reduced rents by 10 per cent., and gave a discount of 5 per cent, on all goods purchased from Government stores, thus contributing considerably to the amelioration of the hardships imposed by the award of the court. I recognize that the Arbitration Court, when considering applications made to it, does, in fact, take into account the economic position of the industry concerned, or, in the case of the Public Service, the economic position of the country. That, I know, has been denied, but the action of the Arbitration Court during the period of the depression fully proves that such is the case. I realise that the position of the men employed on the Commonwealth railways is different from that of those employed by private enterprise. As was stated by the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Drakeford), it was never hoped, when the Commonwealth railways were constructed, that they would .be a paying proposition. It was constructed mainly to give means of communication to Western Australia, when it joined the federation, and it was also regarded as valuable for defence purposes. Therefore, the court could not base its award on the earnings or losses on that line. I was surprised to hear the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr. Drakeford) say that the losses on the various railway systems in Australia are due to low freight charges. It would be interesting to compare the rates in Australia with those in other countries. I point out that the freight rates on Australian railways are from two to three times as high as those in Canada and the United States of America. The Arbitration Court has taken the economic conditions of the country into consideration, and from time to time has restored benefits taken away in times of stress. The Full Court altered the basis of assessing the basic wage in April, 1934, and restored the amount by which the wage was reduced under the financial emergency legislation. Automatic increases of wages have taken place on account of increases of the cost of living. In Kalgoorlie, prior to the award made by His Honour Judge Drake-Brockman, the men were receiving l'2s. 6d. a day less 10 per cent., which made the actual wage l is . 3d." a day, but now rate.is 13s. 8d. a day.

L The question of the hours of work has always been one for determination by the tribunals, and the Government, on this, occasion refuses to depart from the usual practice, and suggests that the men should make application to' the Arbitration Court. The representatives of the employees claim that the court has already refused an application for a 44-hour week. I point out that many applications made from time to time on behalf of the employees' in various industries have been unsuccessful, but the court has eventually acceded to this request when it has found that an industry can afford to grant it. As recently as June last, the court awarded a 44-hour week to the coachbuilders, carpenters, joiners, plumbers and gas-fitters employed on the CommonAvealth railways. Prior to that, the metal trade workers on those railways had enjoyed a 44-hour week for some time. I think it may be said that, when the court deems it advisable to do so, and when the general body of workers in Australia have been granted a 44-hour week, it will give the this boon to all sections of employees of the Commonwealth railways. I believe that that is the objective of all governments. The demands of civilisation require the granting of improved conditions, more leisure, and greater comforts for the workers generally, and I have always said that, as soon as it is possible to grant it, all sections in Australia should be awarded .a 44-hour week. Whilst I believe that governments should be ideal employers, they would not be justified in giving their employees conditions out of all relation to those applying to the general body of the workers throughout Australia. The Government and the Commissioner of Railways have shown that, apart from wages and hours of employment, they are prepared to grant concessions to railway employees. The district allowance is not enjoyed by workers in private employment, but I regard it as a reasonable concession. The conditions under which Commonwealth railway employees live could be materially improved. In some instances, they occupy hovels; I use the word advisedly. It would be disgraceful for any private employer to ask his men to live in such dwellings, and it is all the more discreditable to a government whose employees are associated with a permanent undertaking such as a railway system. The housing conditions should be improved. I entirely agree with the statement that Commonwealth railway employees are peculiarly situated. State railway employees are moved from time to time to districts which give them variety in regard to climate, working and living conditions, but Commonwealth railway employees are confined to semi-arid districts. Apart from the trying climatic conditions under which they live, their children suffer lack of opportunities. On the South Australian railways, somewhat similar climatic conditions obtain on the Peterborough-Cockburn line, but the employees in that locality can be transferred to Adelaide or Mount Gambier, where the living conditions are more pleasant, and their children have ereater opportunities. We have every right to expect the Government to exercise leniency in the conditions and privileges granted to these men. I hope the question of housing in particular will be considered very seriously, because I believe that the conditions under which the men live in some instances are an absolute disgrace. I think that the Government has gone a long way to. assure the men that it is not definitely out to harm them, but, on the contrary, is out to look after their welfare. The very fact that this bill has been introduced by the right honourable member for No r t h Sydney, who has spent a lifetime in advocating the adoption of the system of arbitration in Australia, is at least some assurance that nothing will be done to jeopardize their interests.

Speaker: Mr BLACOTJRN
Title: WOOL TAX ASSESSMENT BILL
text: Bourke) [8.46] I desire to deal with two points as briefly as possible. The Minister (Mr Hughes) accused the Locomotive Engine-men's Union of inconsistency in that, having first desired to go to the Commonwealth Arbitration Court, it now desires to go to the Public Service Arbitrator. Assuming that the right honourable member's contention is correct, the Government itself has been guilty of inconsistency, because it has passed a measure intended to confine government employees to the Public Service Arbitrator only. I know that the Ministei says that that was done accidentally and unintentionally; the fact is that it has been done, and I cannot believe that it was done accidentally or inadvertently. The position was that the High Court in 1933 decided that the Locomotive Enginemen's Union, being a union registered in the Commonwealth Arbitration Court, could approach that court. The Commonwealth Railways Commissioner's answer to that, which was that section 11 of the Arbitration (Public Service) Act prevented such a course being adopted, was overruled. Mr Justice Starke, among other judges, examined that section, and pointed out that it did not prevent the Locomotive Engine-men's Union from going to the Commonwealth Arbitration Court with a two-State dispute, under the Conciliation and Arbitratio n Act : that before the amendment of the A r b i tration (Public Service) Act it could go to the Arbitration Court in either of two ways-it could create a two-State dispute and go to it by right of the federal power to deal with interstate disputes, or it could exercise its special privilege to do so under the Arbitration (Public Service) Act as a union of government employees. Section 11 sub-section 1 of the Arbitration (Public Service) Act 1920 readsNotwithstanding anything contained in the Arbitration (Public Service) Act 1911, an organization of employees in the Public Service shall not be entitled to submit to the Court under that act any claim relating to the salanies, wages, rates of pay, or terms or conditions of service or employment of members of the organization. Mr Justice Starke said in his judgment that only took away the unions' right to approach the court without a twoState dispute. The words " under thai act", had that effect. What did the Commonwealth Government do? It did what the Minister now says was done inadvertently; it introduced during the following year a Statute Law Revision Bill , to which nobody's attention was drawn, the fourth schedule of which amended section 11 of the Arbitration Public Service Act by deleting the words " under that a c t w h i c h Mr Justice Starke had regarded as vitally important aud as securing to the union the right m a two-State dispute to approach the court. Thus, before the bill now under consideration was introduced, it was the desire of the Commonwealth Government to compel its railway employees to go to the Public Service Arbitrator only. It therefore cannot complain of the union's inconsistency. It has showed inconsistency itself by passing an act to compel persons to go to the Public Service A r b i trator, and now by trying to compel them to go to the Arbitration Court. It is always considered that legislation ought not be passed which takes away from persons a right which has already accrued to them. In this case, the union is actually before the Public Service Arbitrator. It is not merely contemplating going before him ; the Arbitrator is at present hearing the case, and this bill will have the effect of preventing the Arbitrator from proceeding any further with the hearing of the case.

Arbitrator; it takes away the jurisdiction of the A r b i trator now. Title: WOOL TAX ASSESSMENT BILL

Title: WOOL TAX ASSESSMENT BILL
text: We tried to get uniformity on paper too. Mr Holloway , - It is of no use to have uniformit y on paper only; the real is to achieve uniformit y in conditions of work, pay and hours of labour. When we examine this matter from that point of view, we find that the brief which the right honourable gentleman holds now on behalf of the Government is a very poor one. In its treatment of Commonwealth railway servants, the Commonwealth Government has shown itself to be the worse employer in this country. Despite what the Minister in his advocacy of uniformit y has said, it is a strange fact that there is a great lack of uniformit y throughout the Commonwealth railway service. No uniformit y of conditions exists in this service as the result of the working of the Commonwealth Arbitration Court. In 1927. But Judge Beeby inquired into the working of the northern end of the North-South railway, and awarded the men certain wages and conditions and a working week of 44 hours. This lack of uniformity must obviously be responsible for the internal discontent among the men which it is desired to eliminate. Railway men proceeding on longservice leave from Tasmania, Queensland, or Western Australia, for instance, can travel all over Australia on a free pass. Speaker: Mr HUGHES
Title: WOOL TAX ASSESSMENT BILL
text: The Commonwealth railway employees get a free pass.

Speaker: Mr HOLLOWAY
Title: WOOL TAX ASSESSMENT BILL
text: But they do not get long-service leave. Compared with the servants of the State railways, Commonwealth railway employees are treated very shabbily. There is no getting away from that, and I can assure honourable members that I derive no pleasure in having to make such an admission. I have travelled over all of the railways Australia, and have observed the conditions under which the men are employed. I have studied the conditions which operate on the northern' and southern end of the North-South line and the Transcontinental line, and I have said here and in other places that the conditions under which the men _ are engaged on those lines are much worse than those operating in any of the States of Australia. The right honourable member for North Sydney knows that the men engaged on the Commonwealth railway system are isolated from the more populous centres of Australia, and are frequently located in places where the climatic conditions leave much to be desired. Because of the loss of social amenities, they should be given improved conditions - Some of the things which I witnessed on the North-South line made me ashamed of being a member of this Parliament. I have seen most of the working agreements that exist in other countries of the world, with regard to not only railway services, but also other services, and I have never come across such bad conditions as operate on the northern end of the North-South line. I was informed that the men engaged there, who are unfortunate enough to suffer injury during working hours, have EO pay their own travelling expenses to a doctor, or to a place where they can obtain first-aid treatment. I asked one of the men whether that was true, and I was informed that in such cases a man had to pay 50 per cent, of the usual fare. I have never come across similar conditions in any part of the world. The poorest private employer would take an injured employee to hospital, and would not expect him to bear the cost of conveyance. I derive no pleasure in exposing things of this kind. All over Australia we should have similar minimum conditions for railway employees whether they operate under a State or Federal award, and special consideration is given when the conditions are unusual. At the present time, four States in the Commonwealth are employing railway men on a 44-hour week. The men employed on the Adelaide to Port Augusta railway and the Commonwealth railway employees on the Transcontinental in line and also the line from Quorn to Alice Springs work 48 hours a week. It is hardly likely that contentment will rule in a service where men have to work four hours a week longer for one employer than men doing the 3ame kind of job have to work for another employer. The introduction of the Commonwealth industrial arbitration system was justified years ago partly on the ground that it would enable uniform conditions to be applied to similar industries throughout the country. Unfortunately that hope has not been realized. The effort to apply a common rule has failed. In the circumstances it is not surprising that men become tired of using orthodox means to rectify their grievances. It is highly regrettable, also, that a Government which professes to favour the adoption of constitutional methods for the settlement of industrial disputes, should reward its own employees who adopt that procedure by withdrawing from them a right which they have possessed for sixteen years. About half the men engaged in our railway works are technicians or artisans who are able to obtain awards irrespective of the views of the Commonwealth Railways Commissioner - I refer, of course, to the blacksmiths, boiler-makers, carpenters, fitters, turners, upholsterers and other artisans who work on our railways. States such as Western Australia, Tasmania and Queensland can afford to give their railway employees a 44-hour week, the Commonwealth should concede similar working hours to its railway employees. I can see no reason whatever for withdrawing from the Commonwealth railway employees the right to approach the Public Service Arbitrator. The mere fact that they have not done so during the last sixteen years is no justification for withdrawing from them the right to do so now. It is strange that on their first endeavour to obtain an award from the Public . Service Arbitrator, the Government should have introduced, a.measure of this description. Probably if the railway employees had taken similar action ten years ago they may have found themselves in the same position. The railway employees have approached the Public Service Arbitrator, not simply because they consider his tribunal better than the Commonwealth Arbitration Court, but mainly because of the thoroughly unsatisfactory experience they have bad in the court in the last eight or nine years. Three years ago the Australian Workers Union and the Commonwealth railway employees submitted a claim to Judge Drake-Brockman which was resisted by the Commonwealth Railways Commissioner. The Judge at that time made an award which obviously was ultra vires the Arbitration Act, but when this was pointed out to him he intimated that he did not intend to be bound by the views of other people. It was well known to everybody at that time that the right of a single Judge to reduce the basic wage or either increase or decrease working hours, had been withdrawn; but Judge Drake-Brockman was not worried by a consideration of that kind. the subject was discussed subsequently in this House the then Attorney-General, Mr Holloway. now Sir John Latham, had to admit that he had a bad case. He moved the High Court, however,, to inquire into the whole position with the result that our discussion of the subject was stifled on the ground that the matter was sub judice. During the whole time that the court was considering the subject the railway employees had withheld from them a certain If proportion of their wages. It is true that, eventually, this money was paid to them, but why should they have been denied the use of it for so long? Undoubtedly it is the experience which the railway men have had with Judge DrakeBrockman in the Arbitration Court that has caused them to seek the redress of their grievances by another tribunal. The Government cannot expect us to accept the argument that this proposal is being submitted to Parliament in the interests of uniformity, for uniformity has not been achieved during the long years that the workers have been looking to the Commonwealth Arbitration Court to redress their wrongs. I am not concerned about the argument that a similar tribunal should be provided for all Commonwealth employees, clerical and otherwise. It is far more important that similar classes of work should be under the jurisdiction of particular tribunals. The Minister has signally failed to justify our acceptance of these cognate bills in the interests of uniformity. As the rail-way workers have been denied justice in the Arbitration Court, they are fully entitled to seek it from the Public Service Arbitrator.

Speaker: Mr BLAIN
Title: WOOL TAX ASSESSMENT BILL
text: Northern .Territory, [9.9] - I rise to protest against the monotonous use of the catch cry "uniformity, uniformity, uniformity and I am amazed that the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holloway) should have joined in the chorus. He could not of course be aware of the real conditions that obtain on the roof of Australia, at Darwin, and also in Central Australia, because he, like most other people, including Judge Drake-Brockman himself, visited the Northern Territory in the winter time. Those who desire to obtain a real understanding of When the humidity, general discomfort and diversity of climate in the Northern Territory, and particularly at Darwin, should do their touring there in the summer time. I am not au fa/it with the con^ ditions of all the railway workers throughout Australia, aud so am at a disadvantage in discussing this subject, compared with the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Drakeford) ; but I propose to draw on my own personal experience to show how illogical it would be to apply uniform conditions throughout Australia; I listened with interest and appreciation to the logical speech which the honourable member for Maribyrnong delivered; but I am not so much concerned, at the moment, whether the railway workers approach the Public Service Arbitrator or the Commonwealth Arbitration Court, as with the injustice of the suggestion that uniform working conditions should be applied even to all railway workers. I assume that the Commonwealth railway employees have good reason for departing from their practice of the last eighteen years by approaching the Public Service Arbitrator in preference to the Commonwealth Arbitration Court. My main purpose in speaking to the bill is to indicate clearly to honourable members that the much more strenuous working conditions in the Northern Territory entitle the workers there to shorter working hours than those enjoyed by workers in the southern parts of Australia. I speak now with an advantage over many honourable members on both sides of the House, because I have myself worked in railway cuttings, and with these hands have used, not a pen as a clerical worker, but a No. 5 shovel, as a navvy on the Narrogin railway in Western Australia. I . well remember old Paddy Donovan saying to me: "Now laddie, get down to it. There's muck waiting for you and a good No. 5 shovel; see that you bury it to the maker's name." If some honourable gentlemen of this House had been with me then in the hottest days of the summer, they would not now be speaking so glibly ahout the desirability of uniform working conditions. The humid climate of the far north is very severe and entitles the workers there to special consideration. To illustrate the effect of these conditions, I shall refer to another personal experience. On one occasion I sent to Rockhampton for an axeman with whom I had worked at Bowen years before. I wanted him to come to the Katherine in the Northern Territory. He agreed to come, and I met him at Camooweal. When I knew this man first he was able to bury a 4^-lb. Kelly axe right up to the eye in green timber. But in the Northern Territory he could not do so, and he was very distressed. He said to me, after he had been working with me for awhile: " I am not going to take £6 10s. a week for the work I am doing here. I cannot do the work here that I did even in Bowen". I said to time: "Do not be. foolish. Men cannot be expected to work here on hard physical toil like they do in other less severe climates". I tried to get him to realise that conditions in the Northern Territory were very different from those of Bowen and-- southern Queensland, but he would not listen to me. He threw up his job, and went away into Western Australia kangaroo shooting. He was too sensitive to work with me, because he could not do the same amount of work in the same time as he was accustomed to do when I first knew him and worked with him. Honourable members must delete the word "uniformity " from their vocabulary when they talk about industrial operations on the roof of Australia at Darwin, and even in Central Australia.

They felt that they ought to approach him that because they assumed that they were or no members of the Commonwealth Public

Title: WOOL TAX ASSESSMENT BILL
text: To whom does the honorway able member refer when he uses the ex

Speaker: Mr CURTIN
Title: WOOL TAX ASSESSMENT BILL
text: The right honourable the gentleman must know that the proceedings in respect of the memorial had proceeded so far that a compulsory conmake ference was held on the 31st January by of this year. Such a conference could there not have been summoned until the side memorial had been submitted in proper form, and rejoinders had been made to it. It is apparent, therefore., that the memorial must have been presented be approximately at the end of last year to permit of a compulsory conference being summoned as early as the 31st January of this year. At that date, when the initial proceedings for this adjudication were in judicial process, there was no suggestion that this Parliament should be asked to annul a law which wa3 then in function. I submit that, by the bill which we are now considering, this Government is interfering with the lawful functioning of the arbitrational procedure which, having been set in motion, the unions believed ought not to be interfered with as the result of political action or political pressure. It would be disastrous if, during'the proceedings incidental to any claim for an award, there should be action by this Parliament depriving either party of the rights which the law gave to it at the time when the proceedings were initiated. That seems to me the outstanding fault of the legislation which the right honourable gentleman has brought down today. It must be obvious to the Parliament that this action is being taken for reasons which he has not stated. He said, in effect, this afternoon: What substantial injustice will be done to the men if they are permitted to go to the Commonwealth Court of Conciliation and Arbitration? With that interrogation, he disposed of the whole matter. I put to him this question: What substantial injustice will be done to the Government if the men are permitted to continue the proceedings they have initiated before the Commonwealth Public Service Arbitrator? Does the Government say that the Public Service Arbitrator will not impartially adjudicate upon the issues that have been submitted to him? Does it ask us to believe that it can entrust postal servants, but not railway employees, to his care? Does the right honourable gentleman contend that it is perfectly proper for the stationmaster at Cook to approach the Arbitrator, but not for the locomotive engine-driver who takes the train from Port Augusta to Cook, to do so? Upon what reasonable premises does he justify the discrimination which this legislation undoubtedly establishes between two employees of the same employer? He asks for simplicity, for definiteness, and for uniformity-if I may use a word about which the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Blain) has discoursed so illuminatingly. I say to him that there never has been uniformity in respect of arbitrational awards, and that, at this stage, any approximation to uniformity in a service so diverse as that of the railway systems of Australia, is inconceivable.' As a matter of fact, the States of Queensland and Western Australia have not, within recent years, appeared before the Commonwealth Court of Conciliation and Arbitration. For the most part, that court has dealt only with the railwayemployees of the States of Victoria,. South Australia, and Tasmania. From his vast experience, .the right honourable gentleman will, I think, agree that the general conditions under which the railway men of Victoria now work, and will continue to work for a decade, are not at all reconcilable with those under which the railway men in the employ of the Commonwealth will work. The railway from Quorn to Alice Springs, and that from Port Augusta to Kalgoorlie, pass through practically empty country. The conditions are anything but genial, and there is no variation of the climate. The honourable gentleman says, " I have taken cognizance of that." If I say to him that his Government has taken cognizance of it belatedly, I am not implying that any censure rests upon him. This is the. first opportunity which he has had to act in this matter. I believe that the men will thank him for the fact that long^service leave, which has hitherto been denied to them, is about to be granted .to them - - But I put it to him that that does not. make the conditions even approximate to the general conditions under which the railway men of Victoria, South Australia and Tasmania work, they being the men who customarily appear before the Commonwealth Court of Conciliation and Arbitration, for the reason that long-service leave is already enjoyed by the great majority of the railway employees of Australia. That is introduced because it is regarded as a reasonable surcease from the monotony of employment, and, in the case of locomotive enginemen, from employment which, in its very nature, imposes a considerable strain. In granting long-service leave, the right honourable gentleman does not give to the Commonwealth railway employees anything which will compensate them for the conditions under which they have to work - He knows that, in Victoria and Western Australia, it is customary to transfer men from semiarid regions to a more congenial station, after they have been stationed in them for some period of years. That certainly is the case in Western Australia, the State of which I have the greatest' knowledge. Railway employees who have been stationed at Mullewa or Meekathara may be transferred to Bunbury, Fremantle, Albany, or Geraldton. In Victoria, those who have been stationed for some time in the Mallee may be transferred to the south-western district, or to some other more salubrious and congenial district, where their wives and families may enjoy some of the compensating virtues which nature itself furnishes. But for the employees on the North-South line' and - the Transcontinental line, the Commonwealth Government has no such resources. ' It can transfer a man from Zanthus; but where to? To a region precisely identical to Zanthus where the north winds still blow and the dust penetrates and where all the adverse conditions that can be .imagined exist, such loneliness for'themselves, their wives their families, and absolute lack of recreational' facilities or entertainment for their leisure hours. They are lated from the general social life of this Commonwealth. No compensation can be given to them in respect of that deprivation except by the fact that they can earn more money in a less period of time than would be the case anywhere else. I suggest to the right honourable gentleman that their hours could be reduced. Government has agreed to allow longservice leave, which we welcome, and to allow the tribunal whichever it be for the time being to decide the question of district allowances. Having yielded those two points which were adamantly opposed by the Commissioner in previous proceedings, a considerable step forward has been made. I now put it to the Minister that 44 hours-should be the maximum working week, having - regard to the inhospitable conditions under which the men have to work and the other conditions which I will not weary the House by repeating, but all of which make reductions of the Mr Curtin. hours of labour reasonable. Without some advantage of hours of labour and rates of pay, but for the existence of unemployment it would be extremely difficult to get labour to man these railways which form one of the essential services of the Australian people. In substance the question the Minister put to us to reply to was, " What substantial injustice would be done to the men to deprive them of the right to go to the Commonwealth Public Service Arbitrator ?" This I answer by stating that the right honourable gentleman has to satisfy, this House that some injustice will be done to the Government in the efficiency of the service by permitting the men to have the option which the law has hitherto given to them. On the question of uniformity I have set out .to establish that there is no general approximation between the conditions of the railway men in the Commonwealth service and the men in the State services. I have travelled the Transcontinental line more often than for reasons of comfort I would have wished. To be a passenger is itself unpleasant, but to have to work on the service is worse. That is one aspect of as the case, but an even more important and aspect is that the great bulk of the Commonwealth servants who are engaged in industrial work, that is to say, men who isoare artisans, mechanics and labourers engaged in the telephone, telegraph, and postal services are to be allowed to remain under the jurisdiction of the Public Service Arbitrator. A postman who is engaged in the service of this Commonwealth at a place like Cook or Alice Springs has more in common with The the railway employee at Cook or Alice Springs than he has with a man of his own occupation 1,000 miles away. Fo'r the purpose of this legislation railway men who have to live at Cook are like the postal officials who have to live there, and it is far safer, on the basis of uniformity, to give them one arbitrator than it is to put the whole of the postal services of Australia under the Commonwealth Public Service Arbitrator and to attempt to put the whole of the Commonwealth railway employees under the Commonwealth Court of Conciliation and Arbitration. I am not seeking to determine which of these tribunals they should have access to, but this Parliament has permitted the railway men to have a choice as to where they will go. In the past they have been allowed access to the Commonwealth Public Service Arbitrator, or to the Commonwealth Court of Conciliation and Arbitration. I ask Parliament to look back on the history of this matter. Is it not true that invariably awards which have been made for these employees have been respected and honoured? Have we any reason to fear that because the men engaged in the railway service now desire, like men engaged in the postal service, to apply to the Commonwealth Public Service Arbitrator they will be less loyal to the provisions of such award as may be made than they have been in the past? What danger is there if the Arbitrator makes an award as between the Commissioner for Railways for the Commonwealth and the employees engaged on the two Commonwealth railways? I ask honourable gentlemen opposite to give to me some substantial reasons for any apprehensions they may entertain that it would be detrimental either to efficiency or to equity and good conscience to give these men the rights that they seek. I reasonably surmise that these bills have been brought down because customarily the employees of the Commonwealth who go to the Commonwealth Public Service Arbitrator believe that they have a reasonable expectation of ting a 44-hour week,_ and because the way employees of the Commonwealth services probably entertain the same hope. The Arbitration Court which does not deal with railway employees in these special regions, but with employees in the more settled cities of Australia, and which probably has no knowledge of the great diversity of conditions and relative severity of hardship of employees in the Commonwealth railway service against those engaged in the State railway services, probably feels that it would be unwise for it to deal with the standard hours other than in the way that has generally been the case. I remind the Minister that it takes three judges of the Arbitration Court to deal with any question of hours. I further put it to him that when a court is dealing with all classes of employees-employee s of private enterprise as well as those engaged in public instrumentalities-that come before it, at least the motives and reasons that animate it in dealing with hours can be understood when it is loth to make changes even with public instrumentalities. When the employees of private enterprise come before it, it may be in an anomalous position if it has granted 44 hours to public instrumentalities and for economic reasons decided to award 48 hours for private employees. Therein lies a case for treatment of those employees in the Public Service by the Commonwealth Public Service Arbitrator, who is engaged exclusively in relationships between the public servants and the Crown. There is a great deal of contention that one cannot impose on private enterprise a shorter working week by any drastic decree of Parliament or by a declaration of the Commonwealth court that would have universal application; but I think I state the facts of the situation when I say that public policy should be primarily responsible for initiating a movement for the reduction of the working week, and that it would not be unreasonable for the Government, which a year ago proclaimed its adherence to a 40-hour week at an international conference, and even went so far as to ask its delegate to vote for a draft convention, the application of which would mean a 40hour week, not to be fearful that get- the Arbitrator would do a ruinous thing railby granting 44 hours on the transcontinental railway and the Central Australian railway. No other thing would warrant the Government interfering with the law than the fear that it has that a 44-hour week may be introduced. If that is not the truth of the matter then the Minister should tell us actually what reasons actuated the Government in bringing down this legislation.

I move That the following new clause be inserted:-" (3) This act shall nut affect the power of the Public Service Arbitrator to determine any claim which has been submitted to him pursuant to the Arbitration (Public Service) Act 1920-1034 before the passing of this act". The object of this new clause is to preserve the right of the unions to proceed with the claims which they have already lodged. Tn accordance with sub-section 2 of section 12 of the Arbitration (Public Service) Act, the unions lodged a claim by memorial, and the Public Service Arbitrator is obliged, in the terms of the act, to determine the matter submitted to him. The position is the same as if a plaintiff had begun an action in a court. It is not a question of altering the law so that a right of action does not exist in future; it is a question of altering the law to take away a right of action which has already been begun. Of course, the law can do that, but it does not as a rule do it. Such action is considered to be unjust, and on a plane with taking away a man's property without compensation. During my speech on the second-reading stage of the bill, I mentioned the action taken by the Minister for Health (Mr Hughes) in connection with the Arbitration Act, when it was proposed to prevent a single judge from altering standard hours. amending section contained a provision that the alteration would not affect proceedings which were then being heard. The principle is well recognized by the English courts. Parliament is not presumed to intend to take away rights to proceed with actions which have been already commenced. It can do so, but the act must clearly show that such is the intention of Parliament. "Without the amendment which I have moved, this measure would clearly indicate that intention. I think that it is only right these proceedings which have already commenced should be allowed to continue. T refer the committee to a point which illustrates this matter very well. At the beginning of this century, an action was decided by the. Supreme Court of Queensland, and the unsuccessful party had a right of appeal to the Privy Council. Then the Commonwealth Judiciary Act. was passed, taking away the right of appeal to the Privy Council, and substituting for it a right of appeal to the High Court. Nevertheless, the appellant went before the Privy Council, and the Council held that he had the right so to appeal to it. The Council admitted that the legislature had the power to take away that right, but pointed out that it was a principle of English law that the legislature must be presumed not to have intended to take the right away unless that intention was clearly stated in the act. In one case, a very distinguished English judge, Mr Baron Pollock, saidJt certainly was considered in many cases that where a person had commenced an action he had a vested right, and that any subsequent statute ought not to be construed as retro-active so as to alter that right. That is not an invariable rule, and it will not apply whore the language of the statute is clearly expressed. If my amendment is agreed to, the Public Service Arbitrator will be obliged to hear those claims that have been already lodged, but all future claims will go before the Commonwealth Arbitration Court. Another case was decided by a distinguished authority, Mr Baron Channell, who said that, in dealing with acts of Parliament which have the effect of taking away rights of action, we ought not to construe them as having a retroThe spective operation,, unless it appears clearly that, such was the intention of the legislature. The cases which I have cited effectively support my view that the Government should not, as a matter of policy, so alter the law as to destroy the right of persons to proceed with actions already commenced.
